paragraphs.name: 2e07
paragraphs.text: Use pointer-events: none along with no opacity to hide elements

paragraphs.name: 40a8
paragraphs.text: Don’t change any properties besides opacity or transform!

A moderately performant way to do things in this category is to treat reaching a certain scroll distance as an event — and just fire things once. Unless you really know what you’re doing, I would suggest avoiding this category since it is so easily to go wrong and really hard to maintain.

paragraphs.name: be5e
paragraphs.text: However, if coded & optimized properly, a mobile experience can be even better a computer. While this was not always the case—and mobile optimization was once pretty tricky—new iPhones are actually faster than most computers. If you’ve been following the previous tips, you may end up with great mobile performance out of the box.

paragraphs.name: 0bda
paragraphs.text: Advanced technique: If you really need to use display: none, you can also delay that with pure CSS, by transitioning the display property and setting a delay.

In many cases, you’ll want to use the CSS transition property to automatically animate an element as it changes. This technique is also known as “tweening”—as in transitioning between two different values. It has the benefit of being easily cancellable or reversible without needing to build all that logic. This is ideal for “set and forget” style animations, like intro sequences, etc. or simple interactions like hovers.

paragraphs.text: This effect could’ve been done with a ton of tiny elements individually animating, or perhaps as an SVG, but that would be unnecessarily complex and probably not be as smooth.

I…

paragraphs.name: d3cc
paragraphs.text: It’s worth noting that Chrome has this built into it’s inspector now. Hit ‘Escape’ and you’ll get a panel appear at the bottom, click on ‘Animations’ and you’re able to set the speed at which they play.

cf8d5d71e158.title: I’m surprised JavaScript’s requestAnimationFrame() method wasn’t mentioned, which is very helpful…

paragraphs.name: 18fc
paragraphs.text: I’m surprised JavaScript’s requestAnimationFrame() method wasn’t mentioned, which is very helpful for optimizing the frame rate distribution in JavaScript based animations. On the topic of CSS clocks, this article explains using requestAnimationFrame to create a smooth live clock: http://www.javascriptkit.com/dhtmltutors/css3clock2.shtml

8cd68ff8f350.title: When using technique #2, you’ll also want to add aria-hidden="true" once the element is hidden, and…

paragraphs.name: c702
paragraphs.text: When using technique #2, you’ll also want to add aria-hidden="true" once the element is hidden, and remove it when it is shown again. This way, screen readers and other assistive technology will skip the hidden element.
A “Pure CSS” solution also exists: https://css-tricks.com/recreating-the-twitter-heart-animation/
